items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is possible this afternoon, Wednesday 28 May, and for at least the next 24hrs. This is due to a natural tide locking effect, and tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth which is restricting the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 29 May, or as the situation changes.

Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides, however high tides will remain high for the next few days in association with this set of springs. We do not expect to issue any further alerts or warnings. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.65mAOD at 04:30 on 29/05/25.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are peaking. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 23 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 08:00 on 29/05/25, or as the situation changes.

Thursday's early morning tide at 01:15 on 29/05/2025 is forecast to be lower than recent days, and accompanied by light Westerly Force 4 winds. The weather still increases tide table values by 0.09 m. The total forecast tide is 5.99 metres Chart Datum (2.94 mAOD) at Littlehampton. Over the next five days, light winds and small waves are forecast, and with tides lower no more than minimal flood impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if property flooding could be possible.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message:
Heavy rainfall is forecast overnight and through tomorrow morning which may cause smaller watercourses to rise. Flooding is possible between 4:00 AM on 29/05/2025 and 12:00 noon on 29/05/2025.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck and other watercourses, from Coniston to Barrow-in-Furness including low lying areas around Ulpha, Duddon Bridge, Broughton in Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Dalton in Furness and Ulverston.
Weather conditions are expected to improve later in the day tomorrow, and no further flooding is expected.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Don't put yourself or others at risk.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 29/05/2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Lancashire, North Yorkshire, Westmorland and Furness

items.message:
Flooding is possible from 11:00 AM on 29/05/2025.
Areas most at risk include River Lune, Conder and Keer and other watercourses from Kirkby Lonsdale to Galgate including Gressingham, Carnforth, Hornby, Wray, Bentham and Lancaster.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Don't put yourself or others at risk.
This message will be updated by 1:00 PM on 29/05/2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: The risk of flooding is reduced with more settled conditions expected. We will continue to monitor the situation and reissue this warning of the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: The risk of flooding is reduced with more settled conditions expected. We will continue to monitor the situation and reissue this alert if the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message:
High tides this evening and the following morning may lead to flooding from overtopping waves.
Flooding is possible between 6:30 PM and 10:30 PM today, Wednesday, 28/05/2025. Further flooding is possible again between 05:30 AM and 10:00 AM tomorrow morning, Thursday, 29/05/2025.
Areas most at risk include The North Sea coast from Mappleton to Spurn Point.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 29/05/2025, or as the situation changes.

The Flood Alert has now been removed. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
The previous tide of concern this morning has now passed,  the conditions are more settled and no further flooding is expected.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.  Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message:
High tides this evening and the following morning may lead to flooding from overtopping waves.
Flooding is possible between 7:00 PM and 10:00 PM today, Wednesday, 28/05/2025. Further flooding is possible again between 06:30 AM and 10:00 AM tomorrow morning, Thursday, 29/05/2025.
Areas most at risk include The Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 29/05/2025, or as the situation changes.

The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides, however high tides will remain high for the next few days in association with this set of springs. We do not expect to issue any further alerts or warnings. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

The Flood Alert has now been removed.
The previous tide of concern has now passed,  the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

Flooding is possible from 10:30 AM on 29/05/2025.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Ribble, Hodder and other watercourses, from Settle to Samlesbury including Clitheroe, Gisburn, Sawley, Waddington and Ribchester.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Don't put yourself or others at risk.
This message will be updated by 1:00 PM on 29/05/2025, or as the situation changes.

Rising river levels tomorrow morning may lead to flooding.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is possible between 7:00 AM on 29/05/2025 and 1:00 PM on 29/05/2025.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River South Tyne, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads.
Further flooding is possible tomorrow afternoon as river levels are expected to remain high due to rainfall.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and checking rivers for blockages.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 29/05/2025, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is affecting low lying land, roads and gardens close to the River Mimram. The situation is now improving with reduced water levels in key hotspots. 

We are monitoring the flooding affecting the Fulling Mill Lane, Singlers Marsh, and Codicote Road areas in Welwyn.  
Flooding to homes and businesses is unlikely at this time, but there may be a risk to very low lying properties or those with basements. River levels in other areas remain below levels of concern. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We are continuing to monitor the situation. 

This message will be updated by 5pm, Wednesday 4th June 2025, or as the situation changes.
The risk of flooding is reduced with more settled conditions expected. We will continue to monitor the situation and reissue this warning if the situation changes.
